001package squidpony.squidgrid.mapping;
002
003import squidpony.ArrayTools;
004import squidpony.squidmath.Coord;
005import squidpony.squidmath.FastNoise;
006import squidpony.squidmath.GWTRNG;
007import squidpony.squidmath.GreasedRegion;
008import squidpony.squidmath.IntVLA;
009import squidpony.squidmath.Noise;
010import squidpony.squidmath.Noise.Noise2D;
011import squidpony.squidmath.Noise.Noise3D;
012import squidpony.squidmath.Noise.Noise4D;
013import squidpony.squidmath.NumberTools;
014
015import java.io.Serializable;
016import java.util.Arrays;
017
018/**
019 * Can be used to generate world maps with a wide variety of data, starting with height, temperature and moisture.
020 * From there, you can determine biome information in as much detail as your game needs, with default implementations
021 * available; one assigns a single biome to each cell based on heat/moisture, and the other gives a gradient between two
022 * biome types for every cell. The maps this produces with {@link SphereMap} are valid for spherical world projections,
023 * while the maps from {@link TilingMap} are for toroidal world projections and will wrap from edge to opposite edge
024 * seamlessly thanks to <a href="https://www.gamedev.net/blog/33/entry-2138456-seamless-noise/">a technique from the
025 * Accidental Noise Library</a> that involves getting a 2D slice of 4D Simplex noise. Because of how Simplex noise
026 * works, this also allows extremely high zoom levels for all types of map as long as certain parameters are within
027 * reason. Other world maps produce more conventional shapes, like {@link SpaceViewMap} and {@link RotatingSpaceMap}
028 * make a view of a marble-like world from space, and others make more unconventional shapes, like {@link EllipticalMap}
029 * or {@link EllipticalHammerMap}, which form a 2:1 ellipse shape that accurately keeps sizes but not relative shapes,
030 * {@link RoundSideMap}, which forms a pill-shape, and {@link HyperellipticalMap}, which takes parameters so it can fit
031 * any shape between a circle or ellipse and a rectangle (the default is a slightly squared-off ellipse). You can access
032 * the height map with the {@link #heightData} field, the heat map with the {@link #heatData} field, the moisture map
033 * with the {@link #moistureData} field, and a special map that stores ints representing the codes for various ranges of
034 * elevation (0 to 8 inclusive, with 0 the deepest ocean and 8 the highest mountains) with {@link #heightCodeData}. The
035 * last map should be noted as being the simplest way to find what is land and what is water; any height code 4 or
036 * greater is land, and any height code 3 or less is water.
037 * <br>
038 * Biome mapping is likely to need customization per-game, but some good starting points are {@link SimpleBiomeMapper},
039 * which stores one biome per cell, and {@link DetailedBiomeMapper}, which gives each cell a midway value between two
040 * biomes.
041 */
042public abstract class WorldMapGenerator implements Serializable {
043    private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;
044    public final int width, height;
045    public int seedA, seedB, cacheA, cacheB;
046    public GWTRNG rng;
047    public final double[][] heightData, heatData, moistureData;
048    public final GreasedRegion landData;
049    public final int[][] heightCodeData;
050    public double landModifier = -1.0, heatModifier = 1.0,
051            minHeight = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeight = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
052            minHeightActual = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeightActual = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
053            minHeat = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
054            minWet = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxWet = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
055    protected double centerLongitude;
056
057    public int zoom, startX, startY, usedWidth, usedHeight;
058    protected IntVLA startCacheX = new IntVLA(8), startCacheY = new IntVLA(8);
059    protected int zoomStartX, zoomStartY;
060
061    /**
062     * A FastNoise that has a higher frequency than that class defaults to, which is useful for maps here. With the
063     * default FastNoise frequency of 1f/32f, the maps this produces are giant blurs.
064     * <br>
065     * Even though this is a FastNoise and so technically can be edited, that seems to have issues when there's more
066     * than one WorldMapGenerator that uses this field. So you can feel free to use this as a Noise2D or Noise3D when
067     * generators need one, but don't change it too much, if at all.
068     */
069    public static final FastNoise DEFAULT_NOISE = new FastNoise(0x1337CAFE, 1f, FastNoise.SIMPLEX, 1);
070
071    /**
072     * Used to implement most of the copy constructor for subclasses; this cannot copy Noise implementations and leaves
073     * that up to the subclass, but will copy all non-static fields defined in WorldMapGenerator from other.
074     * @param other a WorldMapGenerator (subclass) to copy fields from
075     */
076    protected WorldMapGenerator(WorldMapGenerator other) {
077        width = other.width;
078        height = other.height;
079        usedWidth = other.usedWidth;
080        usedHeight = other.usedHeight;
081        landModifier = other.landModifier;
082        heatModifier = other.heatModifier;
083        minHeat = other.minHeat;
084        maxHeat = other.maxHeat;
085        minHeight = other.minHeight;
086        maxHeight = other.maxHeight;
087        minHeightActual = other.minHeightActual;
088        maxHeightActual = other.maxHeightActual;
089        minWet = other.minWet;
090        maxWet = other.maxWet;
091        centerLongitude = other.centerLongitude;
092        zoom = other.zoom;
093        startX = other.startX;
094        startY = other.startY;
095        startCacheX.addAll(other.startCacheX);
096        startCacheY.addAll(other.startCacheY);
097        zoomStartX = other.zoomStartX;
098        zoomStartY = other.zoomStartY;
099        seedA = other.seedA;
100        seedB = other.seedB;
101        cacheA = other.cacheA;
102        cacheB = other.cacheB;
103        rng = other.rng.copy();
104        heightData = ArrayTools.copy(other.heightData);
105        heatData = ArrayTools.copy(other.heatData);
106        moistureData = ArrayTools.copy(other.moistureData);
107        landData = other.landData.copy();
108        heightCodeData = ArrayTools.copy(other.heightCodeData);
109    }
110
111    /**
112     * Gets the longitude line the map is centered on, which should usually be between 0 and 2 * PI.
113     * @return the longitude line the map is centered on, in radians from 0 to 2 * PI
114     */
115    public double getCenterLongitude() {
116        return centerLongitude;
117    }
118
119    /**
120     * Sets the center longitude line to a longitude measured in radians, from 0 to 2 * PI. Positive arguments will be
121     * corrected with modulo, but negative ones may not always act as expected, and are strongly discouraged.
122     * @param centerLongitude the longitude to center the map projection on, from 0 to 2 * PI (can be any non-negative double).
123     */
124    public void setCenterLongitude(double centerLongitude) {
125        this.centerLongitude = centerLongitude % 6.283185307179586;
126    }
127
128    public static final double
129            deepWaterLower = -1.0, deepWaterUpper = -0.7,        // 0
130            mediumWaterLower = -0.7, mediumWaterUpper = -0.3,    // 1
131            shallowWaterLower = -0.3, shallowWaterUpper = -0.1,  // 2
132            coastalWaterLower = -0.1, coastalWaterUpper = 0.02,   // 3
133            sandLower = 0.02, sandUpper = 0.12,                   // 4
134            grassLower = 0.14, grassUpper = 0.35,                // 5
135            forestLower = 0.35, forestUpper = 0.6,               // 6
136            rockLower = 0.6, rockUpper = 0.8,                    // 7
137            snowLower = 0.8, snowUpper = 1.0;                    // 8
138
139    protected static double removeExcess(double radians)
140    {
141        radians *= 0.6366197723675814;
142        final int floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (int) radians : (int) radians - 1);
143        return (radians - (floor & -2) - ((floor & 1) << 1)) * (Math.PI);
144//        if(radians < -Math.PI || radians > Math.PI)
145//            System.out.println("UH OH, radians produced: " + radians);
146//        if(Math.random() < 0.00001)
147//            System.out.println(radians);
148//        return radians;
149
150    }
151    /**
152     * Constructs a WorldMapGenerator (this class is abstract, so you should typically call this from a subclass or as
153     * part of an anonymous class that implements {@link #regenerate(int, int, int, int, double, double, int, int)}).
154     * Always makes a 256x256 map. If you were using {@link WorldMapGenerator#WorldMapGenerator(long, int, int)}, then
155     * this would be the same as passing the parameters {@code 0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256}.
156     */
157    protected WorldMapGenerator()
158    {
159        this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256);
160    }
161    /**
162     * Constructs a WorldMapGenerator (this class is abstract, so you should typically call this from a subclass or as
163     * part of an anonymous class that implements {@link #regenerate(int, int, int, int, double, double, int, int)}).
164     * Takes only the width/height of the map. The initial seed is set to the same large long
165     * every time, and it's likely that you would set the seed when you call {@link #generate(long)}. The width and
166     * height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
167     *
168     * @param mapWidth the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
169     * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
170     */
171    protected WorldMapGenerator(int mapWidth, int mapHeight)
172    {
173        this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, mapWidth, mapHeight);
174    }
175    /**
176     * Constructs a WorldMapGenerator (this class is abstract, so you should typically call this from a subclass or as
177     * part of an anonymous class that implements {@link #regenerate(int, int, int, int, double, double, int, int)}).
178     * Takes an initial seed and the width/height of the map. The {@code initialSeed}
179     * parameter may or may not be used, since you can specify the seed to use when you call {@link #generate(long)}.
180     * The width and height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
181     *
182     * @param initialSeed the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
183     * @param mapWidth the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
184     * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
185     */
186    protected WorldMapGenerator(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight)
187    {
188        width = mapWidth;
189        height = mapHeight;
190        usedWidth = width;
191        usedHeight = height;
192        seedA = (int) (initialSeed & 0xFFFFFFFFL);
193        seedB = (int) (initialSeed >>> 32);
194        cacheA = ~seedA;
195        cacheB = ~seedB;
196        rng = new GWTRNG(seedA, seedB);
197        heightData = new double[width][height];
198        heatData = new double[width][height];
199        moistureData = new double[width][height];
200        landData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
201        heightCodeData = new int[width][height];
202
203//        riverData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
204//        lakeData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
205//        partialRiverData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
206//        partialLakeData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
207//        workingData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
208    }
209
210    /**
211     * Generates a world using a random RNG state and all parameters randomized.
212     * The worlds this produces will always have width and height as specified in the constructor (default 256x256).
213     * You can call {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} to double the resolution and center on the specified area, but the width
214     * and height of the 2D arrays this changed, such as {@link #heightData} and {@link #moistureData} will be the same.
215     */
216    public void generate()
217    {
218        generate(rng.nextLong());
219    }
220
221    /**
222     * Generates a world using the specified RNG state as a long. Other parameters will be randomized, using the same
223     * RNG state to start with.
224     * The worlds this produces will always have width and height as specified in the constructor (default 256x256).
225     * You can call {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} to double the resolution and center on the specified area, but the width
226     * and height of the 2D arrays this changed, such as {@link #heightData} and {@link #moistureData} will be the same.
227     * @param state the state to give this generator's RNG; if the same as the last call, this will reuse data
228     */
229    public void generate(long state) {
230        generate(-1.0, -1.0, state);
231    }
232
233    /**
234     * Generates a world using the specified RNG state as a long, with specific land and heat modifiers that affect
235     * the land-water ratio and the average temperature, respectively.
236     * The worlds this produces will always have width and height as specified in the constructor (default 256x256).
237     * You can call {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} to double the resolution and center on the specified area, but the width
238     * and height of the 2D arrays this changed, such as {@link #heightData} and {@link #moistureData} will be the same.
239     * @param landMod 1.0 is Earth-like, less than 1 is more-water, more than 1 is more-land; a random value will be used if this is negative
240     * @param heatMod 1.125 is Earth-like, less than 1 is cooler, more than 1 is hotter; a random value will be used if this is negative
241     * @param state the state to give this generator's RNG; if the same as the last call, this will reuse data
242     */
243    public void generate(double landMod, double heatMod, long state)
244    {
245        if(cacheA != (int) (state & 0xFFFFFFFFL) || cacheB != (int) (state >>> 32) ||
246                landMod != landModifier || heatMod != heatModifier)
247        {
248            seedA = (int) (state & 0xFFFFFFFFL);
249            seedB = (int) (state >>> 32);
250            zoom = 0;
251            startCacheX.clear();
252            startCacheY.clear();
253            startCacheX.add(0);
254            startCacheY.add(0);
255            zoomStartX = width >> 1;
256            zoomStartY = height >> 1;
257
258        }
259        //System.out.printf("generate, zoomStartX: %d, zoomStartY: %d\n", zoomStartX, zoomStartY);
260
261        regenerate(startX = (zoomStartX >> zoom) - (width >> 1 + zoom), startY = (zoomStartY >> zoom) - (height >> 1 + zoom),
262                //startCacheX.peek(), startCacheY.peek(),
263                usedWidth = (width >> zoom), usedHeight = (height >> zoom), landMod, heatMod, seedA, seedB);
264    }
265
266    /**
267     * Halves the resolution of the map and doubles the area it covers; the 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This
268     * version of zoomOut always zooms out from the center of the currently used area.
269     * <br>
270     * Only has an effect if you have previously zoomed in using {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} or its overload.
271     */
272    public void zoomOut()
273    {
274        zoomOut(1, width >> 1, height >> 1);
275    }
276    /**
277     * Halves the resolution of the map and doubles the area it covers repeatedly, halving {@code zoomAmount} times; the
278     * 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This version of zoomOut allows you to specify where the zoom should be
279     * centered, using the current coordinates (if the map size is 256x256, then coordinates should be between 0 and
280     * 255, and will refer to the currently used area and not necessarily the full world size).
281     * <br>
282     * Only has an effect if you have previously zoomed in using {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} or its overload.
283     * @param zoomCenterX the center X position to zoom out from; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
284     * @param zoomCenterY the center Y position to zoom out from; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
285     */
286    public void zoomOut(int zoomAmount, int zoomCenterX, int zoomCenterY)
287    {
288        zoomAmount = Math.min(zoom, zoomAmount);
289        if(zoomAmount == 0) return;
290        if(zoomAmount < 0) {
291            zoomIn(-zoomAmount, zoomCenterX, zoomCenterY);
292            return;
293        }
294        if(zoom > 0)
295        {
296            if(cacheA != seedA || cacheB != seedB)
297            {
298                generate(rng.nextLong());
299            }
300            zoomStartX = Math.min(Math.max(
301                    (zoomStartX + (zoomCenterX - (width >> 1))) >> zoomAmount,
302                    width >> 1), (width << zoom - zoomAmount) - (width >> 1));
303            zoomStartY = Math.min(Math.max(
304                    (zoomStartY + (zoomCenterY - (height >> 1))) >> zoomAmount,
305                    height >> 1), (height << zoom - zoomAmount) - (height >> 1));
306//            System.out.printf("zoomOut, zoomStartX: %d, zoomStartY: %d\n", zoomStartX, zoomStartY);
307            zoom -= zoomAmount;
308            startCacheX.pop();
309            startCacheY.pop();
310            startCacheX.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheX.pop() + (zoomCenterX >> zoom + 1) - (width >> zoom + 2),
311                    0), width - (width >> zoom)));
312            startCacheY.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheY.pop() + (zoomCenterY >> zoom + 1) - (height >> zoom + 2),
313                    0), height - (height >> zoom)));
314//            zoomStartX = Math.min(Math.max((zoomStartX >> 1) + (zoomCenterX >> zoom + 1) - (width >> zoom + 2),
315//                    0), width - (width >> zoom));
316//            zoomStartY = Math.min(Math.max((zoomStartY >> 1) + (zoomCenterY >> zoom + 1) - (height >> zoom + 2),
317//                    0), height - (height >> zoom));
318            regenerate(startX = (zoomStartX >> zoom) - (width >> zoom + 1), startY = (zoomStartY >> zoom) - (height >> zoom + 1),
319                    //startCacheX.peek(), startCacheY.peek(),
320                    usedWidth = width >> zoom,  usedHeight = height >> zoom,
321                    landModifier, heatModifier, cacheA, cacheB);
322            rng.setState(cacheA, cacheB);
323        }
324
325    }
326    /**
327     * Doubles the resolution of the map and halves the area it covers; the 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This
328     * version of zoomIn always zooms in to the center of the currently used area.
329     * <br>
330     * Although there is no technical restriction on maximum zoom, zooming in more than 5 times (64x scale or greater)
331     * will make the map appear somewhat less realistic due to rounded shapes appearing more bubble-like and less like a
332     * normal landscape.
333     */
334    public void zoomIn()
335    {
336        zoomIn(1, width >> 1, height >> 1);
337    }
338    /**
339     * Doubles the resolution of the map and halves the area it covers repeatedly, doubling {@code zoomAmount} times;
340     * the 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This version of zoomIn allows you to specify where the zoom should be
341     * centered, using the current coordinates (if the map size is 256x256, then coordinates should be between 0 and
342     * 255, and will refer to the currently used area and not necessarily the full world size).
343     * <br>
344     * Although there is no technical restriction on maximum zoom, zooming in more than 5 times (64x scale or greater)
345     * will make the map appear somewhat less realistic due to rounded shapes appearing more bubble-like and less like a
346     * normal landscape.
347     * @param zoomCenterX the center X position to zoom in to; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
348     * @param zoomCenterY the center Y position to zoom in to; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
349     */
350    public void zoomIn(int zoomAmount, int zoomCenterX, int zoomCenterY)
351    {
352        if(zoomAmount == 0) return;
353        if(zoomAmount < 0)
354        {
355            zoomOut(-zoomAmount, zoomCenterX, zoomCenterY);
356            return;
357        }
358        if(seedA != cacheA || seedB != cacheB)
359        {
360            generate(rng.nextLong());
361        }
362        zoomStartX = Math.min(Math.max(
363                (zoomStartX + zoomCenterX - (width >> 1) << zoomAmount),
364                width >> 1), (width << zoom + zoomAmount) - (width >> 1));
365//        int oldZoomY = zoomStartY;
366        zoomStartY = Math.min(Math.max(
367                (zoomStartY + zoomCenterY - (height >> 1) << zoomAmount),
368                height >> 1), (height << zoom + zoomAmount) - (height >> 1));
369//        System.out.printf("zoomIn, zoomStartX: %d, zoomStartY: %d, oldZoomY: %d, unedited: %d, upperCap: %d\n", zoomStartX, zoomStartY,
370//                oldZoomY, (oldZoomY + zoomCenterY - (height >> 1) << zoomAmount), (height << zoom + zoomAmount) - (height >> 1));
371        zoom += zoomAmount;
372        if(startCacheX.isEmpty())
373        {
374            startCacheX.add(0);
375            startCacheY.add(0);
376        }
377        else {
378            startCacheX.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheX.peek() + (zoomCenterX >> zoom - 1) - (width >> zoom + 1),
379                    0), width - (width >> zoom)));
380            startCacheY.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheY.peek() + (zoomCenterY >> zoom - 1) - (height >> zoom + 1),
381                    0), height - (height >> zoom)));
382        }
383        regenerate(startX = (zoomStartX >> zoom) - (width >> 1 + zoom), startY = (zoomStartY >> zoom) - (height >> 1 + zoom),
384                //startCacheX.peek(), startCacheY.peek(),
385                usedWidth = width >> zoom, usedHeight = height >> zoom,
386                landModifier, heatModifier, cacheA, cacheB);
387        rng.setState(cacheA, cacheB);
388    }
389
390    protected abstract void regenerate(int startX, int startY, int usedWidth, int usedHeight,
391                                       double landMod, double heatMod, int stateA, int stateB);
392    /**
393     * Given a latitude and longitude in radians (the conventional way of describing points on a globe), this gets the
394     * (x,y) Coord on the map projection this generator uses that corresponds to the given lat-lon coordinates. If this
395     * generator does not represent a globe (if it is toroidal, for instance) or if there is no "good way" to calculate
396     * the projection for a given lat-lon coordinate, this returns null. The default implementation always returns null.
397     * If this is a supported operation and the parameters are valid, this returns a Coord with x between 0 and
398     * {@link #width}, and y between 0 and {@link #height}, both exclusive. Automatically wraps the Coord's values using
399     * {@link #wrapX(int, int)} and {@link #wrapY(int, int)}.
400     * @param latitude the latitude, from {@code Math.PI * -0.5} to {@code Math.PI * 0.5}
401     * @param longitude the longitude, from {@code 0.0} to {@code Math.PI * 2.0}
402     * @return the point at the given latitude and longitude, as a Coord with x between 0 and {@link #width} and y between 0 and {@link #height}, or null if unsupported
403     */
404    public Coord project(double latitude, double longitude)
405    {
406        return null;
407    }
408
409    public int codeHeight(final double high)
410    {
411        if(high < deepWaterUpper)
412            return 0;
413        if(high < mediumWaterUpper)
414            return 1;
415        if(high < shallowWaterUpper)
416            return 2;
417        if(high < coastalWaterUpper)
418            return 3;
419        if(high < sandUpper)
420            return 4;
421        if(high < grassUpper)
422            return 5;
423        if(high < forestUpper)
424            return 6;
425        if(high < rockUpper)
426            return 7;
427        return 8;
428    }
429    protected final int decodeX(final int coded)
430    {
431        return coded % width;
432    }
433    protected final int decodeY(final int coded)
434    {
435        return coded / width;
436    }
437    public int wrapX(final int x, final int y)  {
438        return (x + width) % width;
439    }
440    public int wrapY(final int x, final int y)  {
441        return (y + height) % height;
442    }

701
702    public interface BiomeMapper
703    {
704        /**
705         * Gets the most relevant biome code for a given x,y point on the map. Some mappers can store more than one
706         * biome at a location, but only the one with the highest influence will be returned by this method. Biome codes
707         * are always ints, and are typically between 0 and 60, both inclusive; they are meant to be used as indices
708         * into a table of names or other objects that identify a biome, accessible via {@link #getBiomeNameTable()}.
709         * Although different classes may define biome codes differently, they should all be able to be used as indices
710         * into the String array returned by getBiomeNameTable().
711         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
712         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
713         * @return an int that can be used as an index into the array returned by {@link #getBiomeNameTable()}
714         */
715        int getBiomeCode(int x, int y);
716
717        /**
718         * Gets a heat code for a given x,y point on a map, usually as an int between 0 and 5 inclusive. Some
719         * implementations may use more or less detail for heat codes, but 0 is always the coldest code used, and the
720         * highest value this can return for a given implementation refers to the hottest code used.
721         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
722         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
723         * @return an int that can be used to categorize how hot an area is, with 0 as coldest
724         */
725        int getHeatCode(int x, int y);
726        /**
727         * Gets a moisture code for a given x,y point on a map, usually as an int between 0 and 5 inclusive. Some
728         * implementations may use more or less detail for moisture codes, but 0 is always the driest code used, and the
729         * highest value this can return for a given implementation refers to the wettest code used. Some
730         * implementations may allow seasonal change in moisture, e.g. monsoon seasons, to be modeled differently from
731         * average precipitation in an area, but the default assumption is that this describes the average amount of
732         * moisture (rain, humidity, and possibly snow/hail or other precipitation) that an area receives annually.
733         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
734         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
735         * @return an int that can be used to categorize how much moisture an area tends to receive, with 0 as driest
736         */
737        int getMoistureCode(int x, int y);
738
739        /**
740         * Gets a String array where biome codes can be used as indices to look up a name for the biome they refer to. A
741         * sample table is in {@link SimpleBiomeMapper#biomeTable}; the 61-element array format documented for that
742         * field is encouraged for implementing classes if they use 6 levels of heat and 6 levels of moisture, and track
743         * rivers, coastlines, lakes, and oceans as potentially different types of terrain. Biome codes can be obtained
744         * with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)}, or for some implementing classes other methods may provide more
745         * detailed information.
746         * @return a String array that often contains 61 elements, to be used with biome codes as indices.
747         */
748        String[] getBiomeNameTable();
749        /**
750         * Analyzes the last world produced by the given WorldMapGenerator and uses all of its generated information to
751         * assign biome codes for each cell (along with heat and moisture codes). After calling this, biome codes can be
752         * retrieved with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)} and used as indices into {@link #getBiomeNameTable()} or a
753         * custom biome table.
754         * @param world a WorldMapGenerator that should have generated at least one map; it may be at any zoom
755         */
756        void makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator world);
757    }
758    /**
759     * A way to get biome information for the cells on a map when you only need a single value to describe a biome, such
760     * as "Grassland" or "TropicalRainforest".
761     * <br>
762     * To use: 1, Construct a SimpleBiomeMapper (constructor takes no arguments). 2, call
763     * {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} with a WorldMapGenerator that has already produced at least one world map.
764     * 3, get biome codes from the {@link #biomeCodeData} field, where a code is an int that can be used as an index
765     * into the {@link #biomeTable} static field to get a String name for a biome type, or used with an alternate biome
766     * table of your design. Biome tables in this case are 61-element arrays organized into groups of 6 elements, with
767     * the last element reserved for empty space where the map doesn't cover (as with some map projections). Each
768     * group goes from the coldest temperature first to the warmest temperature last in the group. The first group of 6
769     * contains the dryest biomes, the next 6 are medium-dry, the next are slightly-dry, the next slightly-wet, then
770     * medium-wet, then wettest. After this first block of dry-to-wet groups, there is a group of 6 for coastlines, a
771     * group of 6 for rivers, a group of 6 for lakes, a group of 6 for oceans, and then one element for space outside
772     * the map. The last element, with code 60, is by convention the String "Empty", but normally the code should be
773     * enough to tell that a space is off-map. This also assigns moisture codes and heat codes from 0 to 5 for each
774     * cell, which may be useful to simplify logic that deals with those factors.
775     */
776    public static class SimpleBiomeMapper implements BiomeMapper
777    {
778        /**
779         * The heat codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 coldest and 5 hottest.
780         */
781        public int[][] heatCodeData,
782        /**
783         * The moisture codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 driest and 5 wettest.
784         */
785        moistureCodeData,
786        /**
787         * The biome codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 60 inclusive. You can use {@link #biomeTable} to look up
788         * String names for biomes, or construct your own table as you see fit (see docs in {@link SimpleBiomeMapper}).
789         */
790        biomeCodeData;
791
792        @Override
793        public int getBiomeCode(int x, int y) {
794            return biomeCodeData[x][y];
795        }
796
797        @Override
798        public int getHeatCode(int x, int y) {
799            return heatCodeData[x][y];
800        }
801
802        @Override
803        public int getMoistureCode(int x, int y) {
804            return moistureCodeData[x][y];
805        }
806
807        /**
808         * Gets a String array where biome codes can be used as indices to look up a name for the biome they refer to.
809         * This table uses 6 levels of heat and 6 levels of moisture, and tracks rivers, coastlines, lakes, and oceans
810         * as potentially different types of terrain. Biome codes can be obtained with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)}.
811         * This method returns a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, so modifying the returned array is discouraged
812         * (you should implement {@link BiomeMapper} using this class as a basis if you want to change its size).
813         * @return a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, a String array containing names of biomes
814         */
815        @Override
816        public String[] getBiomeNameTable() {
817            return biomeTable;
818        }
819
820        public static final double
821                coldestValueLower = 0.0,   coldestValueUpper = 0.15, // 0
822                colderValueLower = 0.15,   colderValueUpper = 0.31,  // 1
823                coldValueLower = 0.31,     coldValueUpper = 0.5,     // 2
824                warmValueLower = 0.5,      warmValueUpper = 0.69,    // 3
825                warmerValueLower = 0.69,   warmerValueUpper = 0.85,  // 4
826                warmestValueLower = 0.85,  warmestValueUpper = 1.0,  // 5
827
828        driestValueLower = 0.0,    driestValueUpper  = 0.27, // 0
829                drierValueLower = 0.27,    drierValueUpper   = 0.4,  // 1
830                dryValueLower = 0.4,       dryValueUpper     = 0.6,  // 2
831                wetValueLower = 0.6,       wetValueUpper     = 0.8,  // 3
832                wetterValueLower = 0.8,    wetterValueUpper  = 0.9,  // 4
833                wettestValueLower = 0.9,   wettestValueUpper = 1.0;  // 5
834
835        /**
836         * The default biome table to use with biome codes from {@link #biomeCodeData}. Biomes are assigned based on
837         * heat and moisture for the first 36 of 61 elements (coldest to warmest for each group of 6, with the first
838         * group as the dryest and the last group the wettest), then the next 6 are for coastlines (coldest to warmest),
839         * then rivers (coldest to warmest), then lakes (coldest to warmest), then oceans (coldest to warmest), and
840         * lastly a single "biome" for empty space outside the map (meant for projections that don't fill a rectangle).
841         */
842        public static final String[] biomeTable = {
843                //COLDEST //COLDER        //COLD            //HOT                  //HOTTER              //HOTTEST
844                "Ice",    "Ice",          "Grassland",      "Desert",              "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYEST
845                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Grassland",      "Grassland",           "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYER
846                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Woodland",       "Woodland",            "Savanna",            "Desert",             //DRY
847                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "SeasonalForest", "SeasonalForest",      "Savanna",            "Savanna",            //WET
848                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "Savanna",            //WETTER
849                "Ice",    "BorealForest", "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", //WETTEST
850                "Rocky",  "Rocky",        "Beach",          "Beach",               "Beach",              "Beach",              //COASTS
851                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //RIVERS
852                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //LAKES
853                "Ocean",  "Ocean",        "Ocean",          "Ocean",               "Ocean",              "Ocean",              //OCEAN
854                "Empty",                                                                                                       //SPACE
855        };
856
857        /**
858         * Simple constructor; pretty much does nothing. Make sure to call {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} before
859         * using fields like {@link #biomeCodeData}.
860         */
861        public SimpleBiomeMapper()
862        {
863            heatCodeData = null;
864            moistureCodeData = null;
865            biomeCodeData = null;
866        }
867
868        /**
869         * Analyzes the last world produced by the given WorldMapGenerator and uses all of its generated information to
870         * assign biome codes for each cell (along with heat and moisture codes). After calling this, biome codes can be
871         * taken from {@link #biomeCodeData} and used as indices into {@link #biomeTable} or a custom biome table.
872         * @param world a WorldMapGenerator that should have generated at least one map; it may be at any zoom
873         */
874        @Override
875        public void makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator world) {
876            if(world == null || world.width <= 0 || world.height <= 0)
877                return;
878            if(heatCodeData == null || (heatCodeData.length != world.width || heatCodeData[0].length != world.height))
879                heatCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
880            if(moistureCodeData == null || (moistureCodeData.length != world.width || moistureCodeData[0].length != world.height))
881                moistureCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
882            if(biomeCodeData == null || (biomeCodeData.length != world.width || biomeCodeData[0].length != world.height))
883                biomeCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
884            final double i_hot = (world.maxHeat == world.minHeat) ? 1.0 : 1.0 / (world.maxHeat - world.minHeat);
885            for (int x = 0; x < world.width; x++) {
886                for (int y = 0; y < world.height; y++) {
887                    final double hot = (world.heatData[x][y] - world.minHeat) * i_hot, moist = world.moistureData[x][y];
888                    final int heightCode = world.heightCodeData[x][y];
889                    if(heightCode == 1000) {
890                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = 60;
891                        continue;
892                    }
893                    int hc, mc;
894                    boolean isLake = false,// world.generateRivers && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.65 && fresh + moist * 2.35 > 2.75,//world.partialLakeData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4,
895                            isRiver = false;// world.generateRivers && !isLake && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.55 && fresh + moist * 2.2 > 2.15;//world.partialRiverData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4;
896                    if(heightCode < 4) {
897                        mc = 9;
898                    }
899                    else if (moist > wetterValueUpper) {
900                        mc = 5;
901                    } else if (moist > wetValueUpper) {
902                        mc = 4;
903                    } else if (moist > dryValueUpper) {
904                        mc = 3;
905                    } else if (moist > drierValueUpper) {
906                        mc = 2;
907                    } else if (moist > driestValueUpper) {
908                        mc = 1;
909                    } else {
910                        mc = 0;
911                    }
912
913                    if (hot > warmerValueUpper) {
914                        hc = 5;
915                    } else if (hot > warmValueUpper) {
916                        hc = 4;
917                    } else if (hot > coldValueUpper) {
918                        hc = 3;
919                    } else if (hot > colderValueUpper) {
920                        hc = 2;
921                    } else if (hot > coldestValueUpper) {
922                        hc = 1;
923                    } else {
924                        hc = 0;
925                    }
926
927                    heatCodeData[x][y] = hc;
928                    moistureCodeData[x][y] = mc;
929                    // 54 == 9 * 6, 9 is used for Ocean groups
930                    biomeCodeData[x][y] = heightCode < 4 ? hc + 54 // 54 == 9 * 6, 9 is used for Ocean groups
931                            : isLake ? hc + 48 : heightCode == 4 ? hc + 36 : hc + mc * 6;
932                }
933            }
934        }
935    }
936    /**
937     * A way to get biome information for the cells on a map when you want an area's biome to be a combination of two
938     * main biome types, such as "Grassland" or "TropicalRainforest", with the biomes varying in weight between areas.
939     * <br>
940     * To use: 1, Construct a DetailedBiomeMapper (constructor takes no arguments). 2, call
941     * {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} with a WorldMapGenerator that has already produced at least one world map.
942     * 3, get biome codes from the {@link #biomeCodeData} field, where a code is an int that can be used with the
943     * extract methods in this class to get various information from it (these are {@link #extractBiomeA(int)},
944     * {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}, {@link #extractPartA(int)}, {@link #extractPartB(int)}, and
945     * {@link #extractMixAmount(int)}). You can get predefined names for biomes using the extractBiome methods (these
946     * names can be changed in {@link #biomeTable}), or raw indices into some (usually 61-element) collection or array
947     * with the extractPart methods. The extractMixAmount() method gets a float that is the amount by which biome B
948     * affects biome A; if this is higher than 0.5, then biome B is the "dominant" biome in the area.
949     */
950    public static class DetailedBiomeMapper implements BiomeMapper
951    {
952        /**
953         * The heat codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 coldest and 5 hottest.
954         */
955        public int[][] heatCodeData,
956        /**
957         * The moisture codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 driest and 5 wettest.
958         */
959        moistureCodeData,
960        /**
961         * The biome codes for the analyzed map, using one int to store the codes for two biomes and the degree by which
962         * the second biome affects the first. These codes can be used with methods in this class like
963         * {@link #extractBiomeA(int)}, {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}, and {@link #extractMixAmount(int)} to find the two
964         * dominant biomes in an area, called biome A and biome B, and the mix amount, for finding how much biome B
965         * affects biome A.
966         */
967        biomeCodeData;
968
969
970        /**
971         * Gets the biome code for the dominant biome at a given x,y position. This is equivalent to getting the raw
972         * biome code from {@link #biomeCodeData}, calling {@link #extractMixAmount(int)} on that raw biome code, and
973         * chooosing whether to call {@link #extractPartA(int)} or {@link #extractPartB(int)} based on whether the mix
974         * amount is lower than 0.5 (yielding part A) or higher (yielding part B).
975         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
976         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
977         * @return the biome code for the dominant biome part at the given location
978         */
979        @Override
980        public int getBiomeCode(int x, int y) {
981            int code = biomeCodeData[x][y];
982            if(code < 0x2000000) return code & 1023;
983            return (code >>> 10) & 1023;
984        }
985
986        @Override
987        public int getHeatCode(int x, int y) {
988            return heatCodeData[x][y];
989        }
990
991        @Override
992        public int getMoistureCode(int x, int y) {
993            return moistureCodeData[x][y];
994        }
995
996        /**
997         * Gets a String array where biome codes can be used as indices to look up a name for the biome they refer to.
998         * This table uses 6 levels of heat and 6 levels of moisture, and tracks rivers, coastlines, lakes, and oceans
999         * as potentially different types of terrain. Biome codes can be obtained with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)}.
1000         * This method returns a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, so modifying the returned array is discouraged
1001         * (you should implement {@link BiomeMapper} using this class as a basis if you want to change its size).
1002         * @return a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, a String array containing names of biomes
1003         */
1004        @Override
1005        public String[] getBiomeNameTable() {
1006            return biomeTable;
1007        }
1008
1009        public static final double
1010                coldestValueLower = 0.0,   coldestValueUpper = 0.15, // 0
1011                colderValueLower = 0.15,   colderValueUpper = 0.31,  // 1
1012                coldValueLower = 0.31,     coldValueUpper = 0.5,     // 2
1013                warmValueLower = 0.5,      warmValueUpper = 0.69,     // 3
1014                warmerValueLower = 0.69,    warmerValueUpper = 0.85,   // 4
1015                warmestValueLower = 0.85,   warmestValueUpper = 1.0,  // 5
1016
1017        driestValueLower = 0.0,    driestValueUpper  = 0.27, // 0
1018                drierValueLower = 0.27,    drierValueUpper   = 0.4,  // 1
1019                dryValueLower = 0.4,       dryValueUpper     = 0.6,  // 2
1020                wetValueLower = 0.6,       wetValueUpper     = 0.8,  // 3
1021                wetterValueLower = 0.8,    wetterValueUpper  = 0.9,  // 4
1022                wettestValueLower = 0.9,   wettestValueUpper = 1.0;  // 5
1023
1024        /**
1025         * The default biome table to use with parts of biome codes from {@link #biomeCodeData}. Biomes are assigned by
1026         * heat and moisture for the first 36 of 61 elements (coldest to warmest for each group of 6, with the first
1027         * group as the dryest and the last group the wettest), then the next 6 are for coastlines (coldest to warmest),
1028         * then rivers (coldest to warmest), then lakes (coldest to warmest). The last is reserved for empty space.
1029         * <br>
1030         * Unlike with {@link SimpleBiomeMapper}, you cannot use a biome code directly from biomeCodeData as an index
1031         * into this in almost any case; you should pass the biome code to one of the extract methods.
1032         * {@link #extractBiomeA(int)} or {@link #extractBiomeB(int)} will work if you want a biome name, or
1033         * {@link #extractPartA(int)} or {@link #extractPartB(int)} should be used if you want a non-coded int that
1034         * represents one of the biomes' indices into something like this. You can also get the amount by which biome B
1035         * is affecting biome A with {@link #extractMixAmount(int)}.
1036         */
1037        public static final String[] biomeTable = {
1038                //COLDEST //COLDER        //COLD            //HOT                  //HOTTER              //HOTTEST
1039                "Ice",    "Ice",          "Grassland",      "Desert",              "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYEST
1040                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Grassland",      "Grassland",           "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYER
1041                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Woodland",       "Woodland",            "Savanna",            "Desert",             //DRY
1042                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "SeasonalForest", "SeasonalForest",      "Savanna",            "Savanna",            //WET
1043                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "Savanna",            //WETTER
1044                "Ice",    "BorealForest", "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", //WETTEST
1045                "Rocky",  "Rocky",        "Beach",          "Beach",               "Beach",              "Beach",              //COASTS
1046                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //RIVERS
1047                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //LAKES
1048                "Ocean",  "Ocean",        "Ocean",          "Ocean",               "Ocean",              "Ocean",              //OCEAN
1049                "Empty",                                                                                                       //SPACE
1050        };
1051
1052        /**
1053         * Gets the int stored in part A of the given biome code, which can be used as an index into other collections.
1054         * This int should almost always range from 0 to 60 (both inclusive), so collections this is used as an index
1055         * for should have a length of at least 61.
1056         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1057         * @return an int stored in the biome code's part A; almost always between 0 and 60, inclusive.
1058         */
1059        public int extractPartA(int biomeCode)
1060        {
1061            return biomeCode & 1023;
1062        }
1063        /**
1064         * Gets a String from {@link #biomeTable} that names the appropriate biome in part A of the given biome code.
1065         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1066         * @return a String that names the biome in part A of biomeCode, or "Empty" if none can be found
1067         */
1068        public String extractBiomeA(int biomeCode)
1069        {
1070            biomeCode &= 1023;
1071            if(biomeCode < 60)
1072                return biomeTable[biomeCode];
1073            return "Empty";
1074        }
1075        /**
1076         * Gets the int stored in part B of the given biome code, which can be used as an index into other collections.
1077         * This int should almost always range from 0 to 60 (both inclusive), so collections this is used as an index
1078         * for should have a length of at least 61.
1079         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1080         * @return an int stored in the biome code's part B; almost always between 0 and 60, inclusive.
1081         */
1082        public int extractPartB(int biomeCode)
1083        {
1084            return (biomeCode >>> 10) & 1023;
1085        }
1086
1087        /**
1088         * Gets a String from {@link #biomeTable} that names the appropriate biome in part B of the given biome code.
1089         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1090         * @return a String that names the biome in part B of biomeCode, or "Ocean" if none can be found
1091         */
1092        public String extractBiomeB(int biomeCode)
1093        {
1094            biomeCode = (biomeCode >>> 10) & 1023;
1095            if(biomeCode < 60)
1096                return biomeTable[biomeCode];
1097            return "Empty";
1098        }
1099
1100        /**
1101         * This gets the portion of a biome code that represents the amount of mixing between two biomes.
1102         * Biome codes are normally obtained from the {@link #biomeCodeData} field, and aren't very usable on their own
1103         * without calling methods like this, {@link #extractBiomeA(int)}, and {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}. This returns
1104         * a float between 0.0f (inclusive) and 1.0f (exclusive), with 0.0f meaning biome B has no effect on an area and
1105         * biome A is the only one used, 0.5f meaning biome A and biome B have equal effect, and 0.75f meaning biome B
1106         * has most of the effect, three-fourths of the area, and biome A has less, one-fourth of the area.
1107         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1108         * @return a float between 0.0f (inclusive) and 1.0f (exclusive) representing mixing of biome B into biome A
1109         */
1110        public float extractMixAmount(int biomeCode)
1111        {
1112            return (biomeCode >>> 20) * 0x1p-10f;
1113        }
1114
1115        /**
1116         * Simple constructor; pretty much does nothing. Make sure to call {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} before
1117         * using fields like {@link #biomeCodeData}.
1118         */
1119        public DetailedBiomeMapper()
1120        {
1121            heatCodeData = null;
1122            moistureCodeData = null;
1123            biomeCodeData = null;
1124        }
1125
1126        /**
1127         * Analyzes the last world produced by the given WorldMapGenerator and uses all of its generated information to
1128         * assign biome codes for each cell (along with heat and moisture codes). After calling this, biome codes can be
1129         * taken from {@link #biomeCodeData} and used with methods in this class like {@link #extractBiomeA(int)},
1130         * {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}, and {@link #extractMixAmount(int)} to find the two dominant biomes in an area,
1131         * called biome A and biome B, and the mix amount, for finding how much biome B affects biome A.
1132         * @param world a WorldMapGenerator that should have generated at least one map; it may be at any zoom
1133         */
1134        @Override
1135        public void makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator world) {
1136            if(world == null || world.width <= 0 || world.height <= 0)
1137                return;
1138            if(heatCodeData == null || (heatCodeData.length != world.width || heatCodeData[0].length != world.height))
1139                heatCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
1140            if(moistureCodeData == null || (moistureCodeData.length != world.width || moistureCodeData[0].length != world.height))
1141                moistureCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
1142            if(biomeCodeData == null || (biomeCodeData.length != world.width || biomeCodeData[0].length != world.height))
1143                biomeCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
1144            final int[][] heightCodeData = world.heightCodeData;
1145            final double[][] heatData = world.heatData, moistureData = world.moistureData, heightData = world.heightData;
1146            int hc, mc, heightCode, bc;
1147            double hot, moist, high, i_hot = 1.0 / world.maxHeat;
1148            for (int x = 0; x < world.width; x++) {
1149                for (int y = 0; y < world.height; y++) {
1150
1151                    heightCode = heightCodeData[x][y];
1152                    if(heightCode == 1000) {
1153                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = 60;
1154                        continue;
1155                    }
1156                    hot = heatData[x][y];
1157                    moist = moistureData[x][y];
1158                    high = heightData[x][y];
1159//                    fresh = world.freshwaterData[x][y];
1160                    boolean isLake = false,//world.generateRivers && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.65 && fresh + moist * 2.35 > 2.75,//world.partialLakeData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4,
1161                            isRiver = false;//world.generateRivers && !isLake && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.55 && fresh + moist * 2.2 > 2.15;//world.partialRiverData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4;
1162                    if (moist >= (wettestValueUpper - (wetterValueUpper - wetterValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1163                        mc = 5;
1164                    } else if (moist >= (wetterValueUpper - (wetValueUpper - wetValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1165                        mc = 4;
1166                    } else if (moist >= (wetValueUpper - (dryValueUpper - dryValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1167                        mc = 3;
1168                    } else if (moist >= (dryValueUpper - (drierValueUpper - drierValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1169                        mc = 2;
1170                    } else if (moist >= (drierValueUpper - (driestValueUpper) * 0.2)) {
1171                        mc = 1;
1172                    } else {
1173                        mc = 0;
1174                    }
1175
1176                    if (hot >= (warmestValueUpper - (warmerValueUpper - warmerValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1177                        hc = 5;
1178                    } else if (hot >= (warmerValueUpper - (warmValueUpper - warmValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1179                        hc = 4;
1180                    } else if (hot >= (warmValueUpper - (coldValueUpper - coldValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1181                        hc = 3;
1182                    } else if (hot >= (coldValueUpper - (colderValueUpper - colderValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1183                        hc = 2;
1184                    } else if (hot >= (colderValueUpper - (coldestValueUpper) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1185                        hc = 1;
1186                    } else {
1187                        hc = 0;
1188                    }
1189
1190                    heatCodeData[x][y] = hc;
1191                    moistureCodeData[x][y] = mc;
1192                    // 54 == 9 * 6, 9 is used for Ocean groups
1193                    bc = heightCode < 4 ? hc + 54 // 54 == 9 * 6, 9 is used for Ocean groups
1194                            : isLake ? hc + 48 : heightCode == 4 ? hc + 36 : hc + mc * 6;
1195
1196                    if(heightCode < 4) {
1197                        mc = 9;
1198                    }
1199                    else if (moist >= (wetterValueUpper + (wettestValueUpper - wettestValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1200                        mc = 5;
1201                    } else if (moist >= (wetValueUpper + (wetterValueUpper - wetterValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1202                        mc = 4;
1203                    } else if (moist >= (dryValueUpper + (wetValueUpper - wetValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1204                        mc = 3;
1205                    } else if (moist >= (drierValueUpper + (dryValueUpper - dryValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1206                        mc = 2;
1207                    } else if (moist >= (driestValueUpper + (drierValueUpper - drierValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1208                        mc = 1;
1209                    } else {
1210                        mc = 0;
1211                    }
1212
1213                    if (hot >= (warmerValueUpper + (warmestValueUpper - warmestValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1214                        hc = 5;
1215                    } else if (hot >= (warmValueUpper + (warmerValueUpper - warmerValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1216                        hc = 4;
1217                    } else if (hot >= (coldValueUpper + (warmValueUpper - warmValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1218                        hc = 3;
1219                    } else if (hot >= (colderValueUpper + (coldValueUpper - coldValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1220                        hc = 2;
1221                    } else if (hot >= (coldestValueUpper + (colderValueUpper - colderValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1222                        hc = 1;
1223                    } else {
1224                        hc = 0;
1225                    }
1226
1227                    bc |= (hc + mc * 6) << 10;
1228                    if(heightCode < 4)
1229                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = bc | (int)((heightData[x][y] + 1.0) * 1000.0) << 20;
1230                    else biomeCodeData[x][y] = bc | (int) ((heightCode == 4)
1231                            ? (sandUpper - high) * 10240.0 // multiplier affected by changes to sandLower
1232                            : NumberTools.sway((high + moist) * (4.1 + high - hot)) * 512 + 512) << 20;
1233                }
1234            }
1235        }
1236    }
1237
1238    /**
1239     * A concrete implementation of {@link WorldMapGenerator} that tiles both east-to-west and north-to-south. It tends
1240     * to not appear distorted like {@link SphereMap} does in some areas, even though this is inaccurate for a
1241     * rectangular projection of a spherical world (that inaccuracy is likely what players expect in a map, though).
1242     * You may want {@link LocalMap} instead, for non-world maps that don't tile.
1243     * <a href="http://yellowstonegames.github.io/SquidLib/DetailedWorldMapDemo.png" >Example map</a>.
1244     */
1245    public static class TilingMap extends WorldMapGenerator {
1246        //protected static final double terrainFreq = 1.5, terrainRidgedFreq = 1.3, heatFreq = 2.8, moistureFreq = 2.9, otherFreq = 4.5;
1247//        protected static final double terrainFreq = 1.175, terrainRidgedFreq = 1.3, heatFreq = 2.3, moistureFreq = 2.4, otherFreq = 3.5;
1248        protected static final double terrainFreq = 0.95, terrainRidgedFreq = 2.6, heatFreq = 2.1, moistureFreq = 2.125, otherFreq = 3.375;
1249        private double minHeat0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
1250                minHeat1 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat1 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
1251                minWet0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxWet0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1252
1253        public final Noise4D terrain, terrainRidged, heat, moisture, otherRidged;
1254
1255        /**
1256         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1257         * as north-to-south. Always makes a 256x256 map.
1258         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1259         * If you were using {@link TilingMap#TilingMap(long, int, int, Noise4D, double)}, then this would be the
1260         * same as passing the parameters {@code 0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256, WorldMapGenerator.DEFAULT_NOISE, 1.0}.
1261         */
1262        public TilingMap() {
1263            this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256, WorldMapGenerator.DEFAULT_NOISE, 1.0);
1264        }
1265
1266        /**
1267         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1268         * as north-to-south.
1269         * Takes only the width/height of the map. The initial seed is set to the same large long
1270         * every time, and it's likely that you would set the seed when you call {@link #generate(long)}. The width and
1271         * height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
1272         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1273         *
1274         * @param mapWidth  the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1275         * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1276         */
1277        public TilingMap(int mapWidth, int mapHeight) {
1278            this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, mapWidth, mapHeight, DEFAULT_NOISE, 1.0);
1279        }
1280
1281        /**
1282         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1283         * as north-to-south.
1284         * Takes an initial seed and the width/height of the map. The {@code initialSeed}
1285         * parameter may or may not be used, since you can specify the seed to use when you call {@link #generate(long)}.
1286         * The width and height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
1287         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1288         *
1289         * @param initialSeed the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
1290         * @param mapWidth    the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1291         * @param mapHeight   the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1292         */
1293        public TilingMap(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight) {
1294            this(initialSeed, mapWidth, mapHeight, DEFAULT_NOISE, 1.0);
1295        }
1296
1297        /**
1298         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1299         * as north-to-south. Takes an initial seed, the width/height of the map, and a noise generator (a
1300         * {@link Noise4D} implementation, which is usually {@link FastNoise#instance}. The {@code initialSeed}
1301         * parameter may or may not be used, since you can specify the seed to use when you call
1302         * {@link #generate(long)}. The width and height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom
1303         * in. Any seed supplied to the Noise4D given to this (if it takes one) will be ignored, and
1304         * {@link Noise4D#getNoiseWithSeed(double, double, double, double, long)} will be used to specify the seed many
1305         * times. The detail level, which is the {@code octaveMultiplier} parameter that can be passed to another
1306         * constructor, is always 1.0 with this constructor.
1307         *
1308         * @param initialSeed      the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
1309         * @param mapWidth         the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1310         * @param mapHeight        the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1311         * @param noiseGenerator   an instance of a noise generator capable of 4D noise, recommended to be {@link FastNoise#instance}
1312         */
1313        public TilingMap(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight, final Noise4D noiseGenerator) {
1314            this(initialSeed, mapWidth, mapHeight, noiseGenerator, 1.0);
1315        }
1316
1317        /**
1318         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1319         * as north-to-south. Takes an initial seed, the width/height of the map, and parameters for noise
1320         * generation (a {@link Noise4D} implementation, which is usually {@link FastNoise#instance}, and a
1321         * multiplier on how many octaves of noise to use, with 1.0 being normal (high) detail and higher multipliers
1322         * producing even more detailed noise when zoomed-in). The {@code initialSeed} parameter may or may not be used,
1323         * since you can specify the seed to use when you call {@link #generate(long)}. The width and height of the map
1324         * cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in. Any seed supplied to the Noise4D given to this (if it takes one) will be ignored, and
1325         * {@link Noise4D#getNoiseWithSeed(double, double, double, double, long)} will be used to specify the seed many
1326         * times. The {@code octaveMultiplier} parameter should probably be no lower than 0.5, but can be arbitrarily
1327         * high if you're willing to spend much more time on generating detail only noticeable at very high zoom;
1328         * normally 1.0 is fine and may even be too high for maps that don't require zooming.
1329         * @param initialSeed the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
1330         * @param mapWidth the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1331         * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1332         * @param noiseGenerator an instance of a noise generator capable of 4D noise, almost always {@link FastNoise}
1333         * @param octaveMultiplier used to adjust the level of detail, with 0.5 at the bare-minimum detail and 1.0 normal
1334         */
1335        public TilingMap(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight, final Noise4D noiseGenerator, double octaveMultiplier) {
1336            super(initialSeed, mapWidth, mapHeight);
1337            terrain = new Noise.InverseLayered4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 8), terrainFreq);
1338            terrainRidged = new Noise.Maelstrom4D(new Noise.Ridged4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 10), terrainRidgedFreq));
1339            heat = new Noise.InverseLayered4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 3), heatFreq);
1340            moisture = new Noise.InverseLayered4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 4), moistureFreq);
1341            otherRidged = new Noise.Maelstrom4D(new Noise.Ridged4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 6), otherFreq));
1342        }
1343
1344        /**
1345         * Copies the TilingMap {@code other} to construct a new one that is exactly the same. References will only be
1346         * shared to Noise classes.
1347         * @param other a TilingMap to copy
1348         */
1349        public TilingMap(TilingMap other)
1350        {
1351            super(other);
1352            terrain = other.terrain;
1353            terrainRidged = other.terrainRidged;
1354            heat = other.heat;
1355            moisture = other.moisture;
1356            otherRidged = other.otherRidged;
1357            minHeat0 = other.minHeat0;
1358            maxHeat0 = other.maxHeat0;
1359            minHeat1 = other.minHeat1;
1360            maxHeat1 = other.maxHeat1;
1361            minWet0 = other.minWet0;
1362            maxWet0 = other.maxWet0;
1363        }
1364
1365        protected void regenerate(int startX, int startY, int usedWidth, int usedHeight,
1366                                  double landMod, double heatMod, int stateA, int stateB)
1367        {
1368            boolean fresh = false;
1369            if(cacheA != stateA || cacheB != stateB || landMod != landModifier || heatMod != heatModifier)
1370            {
1371                minHeight = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1372                maxHeight = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1373                minHeat0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1374                maxHeat0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1375                minHeat1 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1376                maxHeat1 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1377                minHeat = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1378                maxHeat = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1379                minWet0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1380                maxWet0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1381                minWet = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1382                maxWet = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1383                cacheA = stateA;
1384                cacheB = stateB;
1385                fresh = true;
1386            }
1387            rng.setState(stateA, stateB);
1388            long seedA = rng.nextLong(), seedB = rng.nextLong(), seedC = rng.nextLong();
1389            int t;
1390
1391            landModifier = (landMod <= 0) ? rng.nextDouble(0.1875) + 0.99 : landMod;
1392            heatModifier = (heatMod <= 0) ? rng.nextDouble(0.45) * (rng.nextDouble()-0.5) + 1.1 : heatMod;
1393
1394            double p, q,
1395                    ps, pc,
1396                    qs, qc,
1397                    h, temp,
1398                    i_w = 6.283185307179586 / width, i_h = 6.283185307179586 / height,
1399                    xPos = startX, yPos = startY, i_uw = usedWidth / (double)width, i_uh = usedHeight / (double)height;
1400            double[] trigTable = new double[width << 1];
1401            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++, xPos += i_uw) {
1402                p = xPos * i_w;
1403                trigTable[x<<1]   = NumberTools.sin(p);
1404                trigTable[x<<1|1] = NumberTools.cos(p);
1405            }
1406            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++, yPos += i_uh) {
1407                q = yPos * i_h;
1408                qs = NumberTools.sin(q);
1409                qc = NumberTools.cos(q);
1410                for (int x = 0, xt = 0; x < width; x++) {
1411                    ps = trigTable[xt++];//NumberTools.sin(p);
1412                    pc = trigTable[xt++];//NumberTools.cos(p);
1413                    heightData[x][y] = (h = terrain.getNoiseWithSeed(pc +
1414                                    terrainRidged.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs,seedB - seedA) * 0.25,
1415                            ps, qc, qs, seedA) + landModifier - 1.0);
1416                    heatData[x][y] = (p = heat.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc
1417                                    + 0.375 * otherRidged.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs, seedB + seedC)
1418                            , qs, seedB));
1419                    moistureData[x][y] = (temp = moisture.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs
1420                                    + 0.375 * otherRidged.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs, seedC + seedA)
1421                            , seedC));
1422                    minHeightActual = Math.min(minHeightActual, h);
1423                    maxHeightActual = Math.max(maxHeightActual, h);
1424                    if(fresh) {
1425                        minHeight = Math.min(minHeight, h);
1426                        maxHeight = Math.max(maxHeight, h);
1427
1428                        minHeat0 = Math.min(minHeat0, p);
1429                        maxHeat0 = Math.max(maxHeat0, p);
1430
1431                        minWet0 = Math.min(minWet0, temp);
1432                        maxWet0 = Math.max(maxWet0, temp);
1433
1434                    }
1435                }
1436                minHeightActual = Math.min(minHeightActual, minHeight);
1437                maxHeightActual = Math.max(maxHeightActual, maxHeight);
1438
1439            }
1440            double heightDiff = 2.0 / (maxHeightActual - minHeightActual),
1441                    heatDiff = 0.8 / (maxHeat0 - minHeat0),
1442                    wetDiff = 1.0 / (maxWet0 - minWet0),
1443                    hMod,
1444                    halfHeight = (height - 1) * 0.5, i_half = 1.0 / halfHeight;
1445            double minHeightActual0 = minHeightActual;
1446            double maxHeightActual0 = maxHeightActual;
1447            yPos = startY;
1448            ps = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1449            pc = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1450
1451            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++, yPos += i_uh) {
1452                temp = Math.abs(yPos - halfHeight) * i_half;
1453                temp *= (2.4 - temp);
1454                temp = 2.2 - temp;
1455                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1456//                    heightData[x][y] = (h = (heightData[x][y] - minHeightActual) * heightDiff - 1.0);
1457//                    minHeightActual0 = Math.min(minHeightActual0, h);
1458//                    maxHeightActual0 = Math.max(maxHeightActual0, h);
1459                    h = heightData[x][y];
1460                    heightCodeData[x][y] = (t = codeHeight(h));
1461                    hMod = 1.0;
1462                    switch (t) {
1463                        case 0:
1464                        case 1:
1465                        case 2:
1466                        case 3:
1467                            h = 0.4;
1468                            hMod = 0.2;
1469                            break;
1470                        case 6:
1471                            h = -0.1 * (h - forestLower - 0.08);
1472                            break;
1473                        case 7:
1474                            h *= -0.25;
1475                            break;
1476                        case 8:
1477                            h *= -0.4;
1478                            break;
1479                        default:
1480                            h *= 0.05;
1481                    }
1482                    heatData[x][y] = (h = (((heatData[x][y] - minHeat0) * heatDiff * hMod) + h + 0.6) * temp);
1483                    if (fresh) {
1484                        ps = Math.min(ps, h); //minHeat0
1485                        pc = Math.max(pc, h); //maxHeat0
1486                    }
1487                }
1488            }
1489            if(fresh)
1490            {
1491                minHeat1 = ps;
1492                maxHeat1 = pc;
1493            }
1494            heatDiff = heatModifier / (maxHeat1 - minHeat1);
1495            qs = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1496            qc = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1497            ps = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1498            pc = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1499
1500
1501            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1502                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1503                    heatData[x][y] = (h = ((heatData[x][y] - minHeat1) * heatDiff));
1504                    moistureData[x][y] = (temp = (moistureData[x][y] - minWet0) * wetDiff);
1505                    if (fresh) {
1506                        qs = Math.min(qs, h);
1507                        qc = Math.max(qc, h);
1508                        ps = Math.min(ps, temp);
1509                        pc = Math.max(pc, temp);
1510                    }
1511                }
1512            }
1513            if(fresh)
1514            {
1515                minHeat = qs;
1516                maxHeat = qc;
1517                minWet = ps;
1518                maxWet = pc;
1519            }
1520            landData.refill(heightCodeData, 4, 999);
1521            /*
1522            if(generateRivers) {
1523                if (fresh) {
1524                    addRivers();
1525                    riverData.connect8way().thin().thin();
1526                    lakeData.connect8way().thin();
1527                    partialRiverData.remake(riverData);
1528                    partialLakeData.remake(lakeData);
1529                } else {
1530                    partialRiverData.remake(riverData);
1531                    partialLakeData.remake(lakeData);
1532                    int stx = (zoomStartX >> (zoom)) - (width >> 1),
1533                            sty = (zoomStartY >> (zoom)) - (height >> 1);
1534                    for (int i = 1; i <= zoom; i++) {
1535//                        int stx = (startCacheX.get(i) - startCacheX.get(i - 1)) << (i - 1),
1536//                                sty = (startCacheY.get(i) - startCacheY.get(i - 1)) << (i - 1);
1537                        if ((i & 3) == 3) {
1538                            partialRiverData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way();
1539                            partialRiverData.or(workingData.remake(partialRiverData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.4));
1540                            partialLakeData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way();
1541                            partialLakeData.or(workingData.remake(partialLakeData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.55));
1542                        } else {
1543                            partialRiverData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way().thin();
1544                            partialRiverData.or(workingData.remake(partialRiverData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.5));
1545                            partialLakeData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way().thin();
1546                            partialLakeData.or(workingData.remake(partialLakeData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.7));
1547                        }
1548                    }
1549                }
1550            }
1551            */
1552        }
1553    }
1554
1555    /**
1556     * A concrete implementation of {@link WorldMapGenerator} that distorts the map as it nears the poles, expanding the
1557     * smaller-diameter latitude lines in extreme north and south regions so they take up the same space as the equator;
1558     * this counteracts certain artifacts that are common in Simplex noise world maps by using a 4D noise call to
1559     * generate terrain, using a normal 3D noise call's result as the extra 4th dimension. This generator allows
1560     * choosing a {@link Noise3D}, which is used for most of the generation. This is ideal for projecting onto a 3D
1561     * sphere, which could squash the poles to counteract the stretch this does. You might also want to produce an oval
1562     * map that more-accurately represents the changes in the diameter of a latitude line on a spherical world; you
